question: <image 1> The 1933 political cartoon shown above makes the point that
options: ['infighting within and among unions prevented their rise to economic power', 'government inspectors turned their backs to illegal repression of labor unions', 'attacks on unions were so well concealed that the government did not know where to begin its investigations', 'from their beginnings, labor unions were controlled by organized crime']
description: The image is a black-and-white political cartoon from 1933. It depicts two men engaged in a physical altercation. One man, labeled "Strike-Breaking," is dressed in a suit and appears to be attacking the other man, who is labeled "Union-Suiting." The man being attacked is wearing a union suit and is being choked by the "Strike-Breaking" man. In the background, there is another figure, possibly a government inspector or detective, who is looking through a magnifying glass but seems to be ignoring the altercation. The overall scene suggests a conflict between strike-breaking efforts and union activities, with the government inspector seemingly oblivious to the violence occurring.
